A series of lectures, seminars and workshops, that introduce variety of concept of repetition from different culture backgrounds, including Europe, Middle East, China and other countries. Participants are set with briefs and they are expected to respond to these briefs by creating work in different media that is associated with repetition and patterns. The work may include digital media, photograph, 3-dimensional objects and installations.

The objective is for participants to create an innovative living space constructed out of cardboard sheet. They should base the design on an imaginary space that should resemble futuristic shapes and construction by presenting unusual sitting and sleeping areas that does not conform with the norm.
Shakespeare: His Language And His Stories
Shakespeare: His Language And His Stories

In this course we will approach two of Shakespeare’s plays through practical approaches pioneered by the Royal Shakespeare Company in partnership with myself and colleagues at the University of Warwick. The plays will be selected from Hamlet and Twelfth Night. Students will explore the power of his stories as well as his dramatic language and will experiment with ways of finding fresh interpretations to make the plays live in performance.

This course will introduce students to a unique form of theatre, pioneered in the UK by the renowned director Mike Alfreds (the mentor of Mark Rylance) and developed by myself at the University of Warwick. Students will explore stories suitable for audiences of different ages and from different cultural sources, and how to adapt them for performance using both narrative and characterization. Issues of meaning and relevance will be as significant as learning a set of highly challenging performance skills. Students will have the opportunity to work on their own performances to conclude the course.

《影视照明技术》布莱恩?布朗著，中国传媒大学出版社
《影视照明》戴维?维拉著，复旦大学出版社
提高编导专业本科学生对灯光的感性认知能力，以及实际操作能力，为微影视作品的具体拍摄打下不可或缺的基础。培养编导本科学生对影视灯光的认识以及实际运用能力，获得微电影级的灯光设计操作水平。
灯光在拍摄中占有首要地位，也是影视艺术最原始的、最基本的表现手段，也是最年轻的、最新的表现手段。影视艺术令人最感兴趣的手段是光线和色彩。对光和色技巧的研究，是学生必须再探讨、掌握的部分
《广播电视节目制作》 中国传媒大学出版社
提高编导专业学生对电视节目制作流程的认识，重视节目制作实际操作，加强制作节目的计划性，遵循制作流程的科学性，提高制作节目的质量和效率。培养编导专业学生在初步掌握相关知识后，在教师的指导下实际完成某一具体的节目制作与合成，为今后步入社会打下良好的基础，让学生在专业领域得到更多的认同。
本课程介绍了电视节目制作历史及其目下的现实状况，重点讲解电视节目制作的规律和电视节目构思与策划。重点要求学生重点掌握电视节目制作的要领，能够独立完成电视节目的制作。\x02\x04\x05？
Appreciation of Popular Music in Western Cinema
Appreciation of Popular Music in Western Cinema

This very popular course from the 2014 Sichuan University UIP will use illustrated lectures and video screenings of selections from Hollywood cinema, both dramatic and documentary. The lectures and screenings will feature films that dramatically create visual narratives, storytelling, drama, and emotional content in the cinema. The lectures and screenings will include a dynamic range of cinema genres including comedy, mystery, romance, and documentary. Film-makers to be included are Quentin Tarantino, Bradley Beesley, Oliver Stone, Anton Corbijn, Robert Frank, and Margaret Brown. The lectures will introduce students to the ways that films and screenings use music. Students will be challenged to consider what is achieved by the use of music and how a “soundtrack” is a narrative device.  A final exam will be given and a study guide will be provided prior to the exam.

Introduction to World of Musics focuses on selected musical traditions from around the world. The course is designed to help students (1) understand the importance of music as a human (and humanizing) activity, (2) appreciate the diversity of musical expressions and cultural values in the world, (3) learn the distinctive qualities of different musics, and (4) enjoy all musics more fully. We will listen to, watch, and read about lots of music.
新媒体概念及新媒体艺术实践
The concept analysis and art practice of new media

《媒介形态变化：认识新媒介》（美）菲德勒著  华夏出版社  2000-1-1
《数字化崇拜:迷思、权力与赛博空间》 文森特·莫斯可  北京大学出版社 2010年版
《赛博空间的奥德赛:走向虚拟本体论与人类学》 约斯·德·穆尔  广西师范大学出版社 2007版

本课程的目标为引导学生全面地认识“新媒体”概念中有关社会学、经济学、美学和叙事表达等方面的内涵，引导学生了解和探索当前“新媒体”艺术的创作理念和表达方式。课程将运用西方发达国家在传媒研究（Media Studies）和网络文化研究（Cyber-culture Studies）方面的系统框架来分层面解析“新媒体”概念，使学生较全面地了解当前有关新媒体的诸多研究方向和话题，从而更好地前瞻影视艺术创作与新技术融合后的发展趋势；本课还将引介目前网络艺术的种种实践方式和经验，扩展学生有关视像艺术表达的思路和能力。

本课程的目标为引导学生全面地认识“新媒体”概念中有关社会学、经济学、美学和叙事表达等方面的内涵，引导学生了解和探索当前“新媒体”艺术的创作理念和表达方式。课程将运用西方发达国家在传媒研究（Media Studies）和网络文化研究（Cyber-culture Studies）方面的系统框架来分层面解析“新媒体”概念，使学生较全面地了解当前有关新媒体的诸多研究方向和话题，从而更好地前瞻影视艺术创作与新技术融合后的发展趋势；本课还将引介目前网络艺术的种种实践方式和经验，扩展学生有关视像艺术表达的思路和能力。

Transforming the Teaching of Shakespeare with the Royal Shakespeare Company
Transforming the Teaching of Shakespeare with the Royal Shakespeare Company

In this course we will approach important work of the Royal Shakespeare Company through practical approaches. The plays will be selected from Macbeth ,As you like it and so on . Students will explore the power of his stories as well as RSC rehearsal technique and will experiment with ways of finding fresh interpretations to make the plays live in performance.

This course will introduce students to an implicit suggestion of a mirror educational process which is based on the assumption that it should be geared to students experimenting with theatre in an active inquiry model in order to discover more about human experience and the aesthetic possibilities of theatre through: 1 the active study and performance of theatre texts
2 experiencing ,as spectators and as action,.a variety of world theatre styles
and genres as well as experiencing the diversity of conventions within
each style
3 using conventions to experience and to translate, depict and transform
personal and social meanings
Ink Painting in the Postmodern Era
Ink Painting in the Postmodern Era

Dating back more than 2000 years, Chinese Ink Painting has been through various stages of development and always has a sense of abstraction in its brushwork. However,except for the exploration on spatial arrangement by Ming Dynasty artist Dong Qichang and a few experimental ink painters in recent years, pure abstraction and other modern, postmodern and contemporary pictorial organizations and approaches within the ink painting medium havenever been fully developed, which hinders the progression of ink painting and itsfull participation in the international contemporaryart world. Since the evolution of painting is partially judged by the compositional organization and the way the images are constructed,ink painting is often seen by the Western art critics as a traditional and ethnic painting medium unlike oil and acrylic mediums. On the one hand, for the vitality and liveliness of ink painting, we hope that this painting medium will continue to grow along with the development of our society into the postmodern world; on the other hand, since ink medium has many unique visual effects, concepts and philosophies that are related to and complement of modern Western art, we hope it will become a popular and vital medium internationally. With these intentions and expectations in mind, reformation and progression of ink painting medium become an important and crucial topic for discussion and exploration among contemporary Chinese artists. In order to nourish and facilitate such development, this course examines the concepts and techniques of abstraction, modernism, postmodernism, and other contemporary art forms in Western art history with an aim to help ink painters break free from the rigid constraints of the ink painting tradition. Experimental,creative, and individual artistic development in ink medium for each student will be emphasizedand multimedia approaches will also been encouraged and explored. Lecture, analysis, demo, reading,research, presentation, studio practice, artist statement writing, critical thinking skill, critique, and discussion will be the themes and methods of instructionin this course. Specific class projects include ppt presentation of his/her own portfolio, research of related artists and present the research to the whole class, discussion of critical essays, reviews, and art related videos, writing and critique of artist statement, individual and group critique of works in progress, etc. Students are encouraged to pursue a focused personal vision through a combination of self-directed studio practice and critique integrated with the study of historical and contemporary art theory. Studio component and instruction are tailored to the student’s individual investigations. The ultimate goal is for students to develop his/her own visually coherent and conceptually unified body of work.
Oil Painting in the Postmodern World
Oil Painting in the Postmodern World

Oil painting has been imported to China for hundredsof years and it is now one of the major painting mediums in China. Yet the prevailing painting style in China is limited to realism; explorations in abstraction, modernism, postmodernism, and other contemporary art forms have not been emphasized enough in the Chinese educational system, which hinders the healthy advancement of contemporary Chinese art. Apparently, since the evolution of paintingis partially judged by its compositional organization and the way the images are constructed, majority of the Chinese oil painting is considered conservative and traditional by Western critics, resulting in a limitedrecognition and participation in the international art world in major art centers such as London, Paris, Frankfurt, and New York. In order to nourish and facilitate such an experimental, creative, and individual artistic development among young oil painters in China, this course examines the concepts, techniques, and styles of abstraction, modernism, postmodernism, and other contemporary art forms in Western art history with the hope to help Chinese students go beyond classical representational painting style. Incorporation with digital media (Photoshop, projection, inkjet printing, etc.) in oil painting process will be explored. Lecture, analysis, reading,research, presentation, studio practice, artist statement writing, critical thinking skill, critique, and discussion will be the themes and methods of instructionin this course. Specific class projects include ppt presentation of his/her own portfolio, research of related artists and present the research to the whole class, discussion of critical essays, reviews, and art related videos, writing and critique of artist statement, individual and group critique of works in progress, etc. Students are encouraged to pursue a focused personal vision through a combination of self-directed studio practice and critique integrated with the study of historical and contemporary art theory. Studio component and instruction are tailored to the student’s individual investigations. The ultimate goal is for students to develop his/her own visually coherent and conceptually unified body of work.

Study of major artists and art movements in the United States of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries exploring the European influences on the American art, as well as the innovations of the artists as they painted the people and places of country.

This course will examine the lives and works of major Impressionist artists; their immediate forerunners, the Realists; and their successors, the Post-Impressionists, covering a period from the mid-nineteenth to the early twentieth centuries. The class will look closely at these artists within the cultural, social, and economic context of their time, by exploring a number of overarching themes such as subject matter, gender issues, influences, and modernity.
Making the Invisible Visible: an Introduction to Ethnography
Making the Invisible Visible: an Introduction to Ethnography

Ethnography, one of the most popular and fastest growing methods for conducting qualitative research, has many applications for understanding human behavior in social settings. This methodology involves systematic description and documentation of culture, an “invisible" knowledge system by which people share meaning. It also offers insight to identifying problems and finding solutions to create more effective interactional situations in work, education, and community contexts. An overview of cultural anthropology principles will provide information about where, when, why, and how researchers use ethnographic strategies. Students will view videos of diverse cultural contexts as well as visit actual field sites to practice participant-observation techniques that involve taking field notes. Various frameworks for studying social interaction will be investigated to shift and focus attention on meaning making processes. Students also will learn basic data coding for comparative analysis to reveal new insights about people and their cultures. The course structure will consist of six two-hour sessions.

Inspired by the natural world, students will explore expressive modalities such as drawing, storytelling, poetry, dance/movement, song, playing music, sculpture, and/or other art forms to promote personal balance and deeper knowledge of self and others. This practice, referred to as eco-somatic arts, facilitates creative engagement with the non-human environment. One does not need to be an “artist” and the course is not about learning art skills. Instead it provides a framework for discovering the experiential process of art-making as a tool for expanding awareness of the interconnection between nature and all life. Based on eco-therapy and eco-psychology, the work has important ramifications for increasing individual and societal wellbeing in which the Earth serves as teacher. Examples from around the world and throughout history will demonstrate how and why nature is a powerful creative resource and is used by such people as artists, scientists, urban planners, social workers, medical professionals, and therapists to understand human-environmental sustainability. The course structure will consist of six two-hour sessions.
